div.p: was 220. On entering the Camp I was conducted by one of their eminent Chiefs to his Tent, to whom I had been recommended by the Borgne through the medium of the other Shawyens[.] I was actually looked upon as the Borgne's Son, though they knew I was a White man[.] My new Host after giving me to eat of the best Which this lodge & the Camp could afford made a long harrangue, commanding those that had furs to come & trade them with Son of the Gros Ventres Chief – which they readily obliged so that before sun set I had not a Single article for remaining nor had they any thing to trade excepting Buffalo Robes which being well garnished they Kept or asked a higher price for, than they were worth[.] However I sold the few art. I had to advantage having got about a hundred weight of Beaver, 4 of the finest Bear Skins thus ever I had seen together with some fine B. Robes[.] My furs being tied up I went to see Monsieur Gissom, who I found very pensive sitting in a lodge smoking his pipe[.] After enquiring what was his success, he told me that it was less than he had a right to expect, but that I was the cause of it – for said he, they were bringing me furs very fast when you sent a man through the Camp harranguing that you would pay high prices for their Beaver, & those who had some in their hands to throw on my pipe turned on their heels & went to you with them, & since that time I got only few Robes[.] So continued he for my Gun, cloth, Ax, ammunition, & horse, I got an inferior horse to the one I had given: 3 Beaver skins & 6 B. Robes[.]

Had I put myself in their Powder as you wished me to have done[,] I should not have a fourth of what I have at present, said I, & Monsr I told you all along that you would be a looser[.] But he said – Il faut faire comme cela pour être considrés par les Sauvages[.] The Gros Ventres were much caressed by the Shawyens & we all agreed to remain six days with them on condition that they should
